image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Virginia; born on a farm near Franklin, Southampton County, Va., February 11, 1897; attended the public schools; was graduated from the University of Virginia at Charlottesville in 1922 and from Columbia University, New York City, in 1923; awarded a Carnegie Fellowship to Oxford University, England, in 1924; during the First World War served with the French Army in 1916 and 1917 and later as a lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps Air Service; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1922 and commenced practice in Norfolk, Va.; member of the State house of delegates 1930-1933; elected as a Democrat to the Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Congresses (March 4, 1933-January 3, 1937); unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1936; again elected to the Seventy-sixth and Seventy-seventh Congresses and served from January 3, 1939, until his resignation in March 1, 1941, to become a candidate for Governor; Governor of Virginia from January 21, 1942, to January 16, 1946; president of the University of Virginia at Charlottsville from June 23, 1947, to September 1, 1959; United States delegate to the Tenth General Assembly of the United Nations, 1955; presidential appointment to Commission on National Goals, 1960; chairman, Commission on Goals for Higher Education in the South, 1961; resided in Norfolk, Va., where he died June 9, 1981; interment on family estate, Southampton, Va.

researchRecord.name: 1950, 1 letter.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Harry Rogers Pratt to University of Virginia President Colgate Whitehead Darden, Jr. describing his delivery of the vocal and piano score of Randall Thompson's Testament of Freedomto Carr's Hill and relating the background of its composition for the celebration of the 200th Anniversary of Thomas Jefferson's birth. Pratt says about the piece, "Its composition and two performances make history and pull close together the political wisdom of Thomas Jefferson and the idealism of Franklin Roosevelt." He also notes that Randall Thompson's Testament of Freedomwas performed a few minutes before the funeral service for Roosevelt began in the Capitol. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.

researchRecord.name: 1975, 9 items.
researchRecord.description: Interviews of James Latimer with Colgate Whitehead Darden and William Munford Tuck. The two former governors discuss Virginia politics during the first half of the 20th century in conversations filmed for WCVE Richmond. Topics discussed include Darden and Tuck's personal backgrounds and political histories; Harry Byrd and his influence on the Democratic Party in Virginia and on state fiscal policies; prohibition and the role of Methodist Bishop James Cannon, Jr.; President Truman's visit to the state and relationships with him; school desegregation and the state's policy of "massive resistance" to it; Churchill's 1946 visit to Virginia; and the state's political future.
